title: How do i support?
body:
I get that you need to help your adc carry and later your team and that I have to ward at least 40 times a game. Yet that is not helpful when I don't know the most efficient way to place wards and get back to lane to "pull my pants up" or how many wards I need to but to balance my build so I don't overspend ect

What is an easy way to describe some pro tips that I can use to help myself?

Any help appreciated ;)

replies.body:
Usually you want to build sightstone first item on most supports so you don't "waste" too much money on wards. I know pros prefer Boots + wards on thier first back but whatever.

You pretty much want to average a ward a minute or so in terms of numbers if that helps you out.
Usually I try to have my first back when I get about 950-1000 gold. Buy {{item:2049}} {{item:3341}} {{item:2043}}  and poitions if needed.
If you have to back on less gold, usually either {{item:1001}} + 2 {{item:2044}}  OR {{item:1028}} + 2 {{item:2044}} is a good buy.

Knowing where is pretty simple. Where you need vision to either protect yourself from ganks or keep an eye on objectives.

Tri-brush is a good place for a pink ward if you are blue side.  A ward in front of dragon pit keeps dragon warded and river warded for roams/ganks.
Putting a deep ward at the enemy blue/red buff can help keep an eye on the junglers movements too.

Leave lane to ward when either the enemy is gone and your ADC is not in danger so you have spare time. Or you can go ward after you back, walk and ward then go back to lane. Just make sure if you do leave to tell your ADC with pings or chat that you are leaving so they should play safe.
Also a tip for support, never upgrade to a {{item:2045}} until late in the game. Its a big waste of money to get it early.

This is my experience from 2 years main sup:
1. Ward is always need and you do not only need to ward, you also need to warn your team mate due to sometimes you have ward but they just ignore the mini map.
2. You need to learn how to rotate to help other lane not just you adc. With this I can only said play a lot and you will learn how to do this.
3. You always need at least {{item:2043}} every time you want to go on big object such as dragon, baron, sometime even just to make sure they don't have ward behind you when you go high ground.
4. Protect your carry in team fight: If your carry too dumb to go on team fight, ignore that guy, let him die. If your carry is super good, buy everything you can to help him, not you, him. Like {{item:3222}} {{item:3190}} or even {{item:3504}} to make sure he can win your team fight.
5. Last one, do not try to highlight yourself, let the carry get the compliment, like if you give him double kill, said "GJ ...", be the background. I know support doesn't mean you get nothing but you know you did well is fine.

{{item:2044}} {{item:2043}} are often placed in brush but does not need to always. 

Ward the tribrush if you're on the blue side of the map. Often it's best to take vision ward for that brush later in the game because it is on your side of the map and will be easier to clear out any sight wards that will be placed.

An example of when it is okay to put vision wards outside of brushes is when your team is trying to secure dragon. If you place a Vision ward on the entrance of the dragon pit you will be able to see most of the sight wards in the pit and pretty much all of the sight wards that might be placed outside. Sometimes players use another vision ward and place it within the dragon pit because players can place wards to the back of the wall (behind the wall of the entrances) there is a blindspot if vision wards are placed outside the dragon pit.

You can "extend" your ward range through some **parts** of thick walls.

Depends a lot on what supports you're playing, but mastering items is a pretty big deal on supports. A lot of support items have actives (tier 3 of gp5 items, mikaels, aegis, randuins), so being able to use them effectively along with your normal spells is pretty key!

The janna 6 active support for example that i play.

FQC, SightStone, Mikael's, locket, twin shadows, trinket, and mobi's with homeguards.

But the main thing is the "40 ward" sort of mentality is shit, ward where you need them, sure in a 30 minute game you can get 40 wards down, though probably only 25 or less will be useful.

I am going to add this suggestion.

You have to pay attention to the map and use smart pings to communicate with your team what your wards are saying. You put those wards down and it's your job to interpret the information they give. Your team doesn't know why you put X ward in X location, all they know is they either have wards or not. You really have to pay extra attention to the map.

Also you don't always have to ward in bushes. Even with Vision Wards, as eventually supports learn the ranges of vision wards from brushes and ward just out of range.

1. What matters most is where wards are placed not how many you've placed. 
2. Mobi's rush offers catch potential in lane and map pressure. 2 trinkets and buying a ward does the job of a Sightstone during lane phase as long as you're smart and keep tabs on their Jungler/Mid.
3. Use {{item:3302}} and {{item:3303}} in lane phase then buy {{item:3069}} when your team starts grouping. 
4. Ignite is meta you should be running it every game unless you're vsing assassins and your team has low/no CC to deal with them.
5. Don't die too much.
